statement.text: An Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a permanent, localized dilation of the abdominal aorta to a diameter ≥3.0 cm, or >50% larger than the normal aortic diameter, involving all three layers of the arterial wall (intima, media, adventitia). The infrarenal aorta is the most common location.
statement.formal: AAA: True aneurysm (all 3 layers involved) of abdominal aorta where diameter ≥3.0 cm OR diameter >1.5× reference diameter

explanation.intuition: Think of an aneurysm like a weak spot in a garden hose that balloons outward under pressure. In the aorta, the largest artery in the body, this weakening allows the wall to stretch and dilate. Unlike a pseudoaneurysm (which is a contained rupture), a true aneurysm involves all three layers of the blood vessel wall expanding together.
explanation.key_insight: The 3.0 cm threshold is clinically significant because the normal infrarenal aortic diameter is approximately 1.5-2.0 cm, making 3.0 cm roughly 1.5 times normal. This threshold represents the point at which the vessel is pathologically dilated and warrants surveillance.
explanation.technical_details: AAA formation results from a complex interplay of genetic predisposition, hemodynamic stress, and arterial wall degeneration. The infrarenal location is most common (95% of AAAs) due to reduced vasa vasorum, lower elastin content, and increased wall stress from the aortic bifurcation reflection wave. Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) degrade elastin and collagen, weakening the media and allowing progressive dilation.
common_misconceptions: All aortic dilations are aneurysms - ectasia (dilation 2.5-3.0 cm) is not yet an aneurysm
AAA is the same as aortic dissection - they are distinct pathologies
All AAAs need immediate surgery - most are managed with surveillance
AAA only affects men - women also develop AAA, though less commonly

definitions_glossary.aneurysm: Permanent, localized arterial dilation involving all wall layers, >50% normal diameter
definitions_glossary.true_aneurysm: Dilation involving all three arterial wall layers (intima, media, adventitia)
definitions_glossary.pseudoaneurysm: Contained rupture with blood contained by surrounding tissue, not all wall layers
definitions_glossary.aorta: The main artery carrying blood from the heart to the body
definitions_glossary.ectasia: Arterial dilation less than 50% above normal, typically 2.5-3.0 cm for infrarenal aorta

epidemiology.prevalence: 4-8% in men over 65, 0.5-1.5% in women over 65

natural_history.growth_rate: Average 2-3 mm per year, accelerates with larger diameter

definition.@value: Permanent localized dilation of the abdominal aorta to diameter ≥3.0 cm or >50% larger than normal, involving all three arterial wall layers

prerequisites.title: Arterial System
prerequisites.reason: AAA occurs in the arterial system

prerequisites.title: Atherosclerosis
prerequisites.reason: Atherosclerosis is a major risk factor for AAA

prov:wasDerivedFrom.dc:title: Society for Vascular Surgery clinical practice guidelines for the management of AAA
prov:wasDerivedFrom.dc:creator: Society for Vascular Surgery

prov:wasDerivedFrom.dc:title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 10th Edition

sources.citation: Chaikof EL, Dalman RL, Eskandari MK, et al. SVS practice guidelines for the care of patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. J Vasc Surg. 2018;67(1):2-77.e2.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 10th Edition

learning_objectives: Define abdominal aortic aneurysm using standard criteria
Distinguish true aneurysm from pseudoaneurysm and ectasia
Identify the most common anatomic location for AAA
Understand the significance of the 3.0 cm threshold
common_errors: Not recognizing that most AAAs are asymptomatic
Using diameter alone without considering growth rate
Applying male size thresholds to female patients
clinical_pearls: Normal infrarenal aortic diameter: ~2.0 cm in men, ~1.7 cm in women
AAA is often an incidental finding on imaging for other conditions
Presence of AAA strongly correlates with other aneurysms (popliteal, iliac)
